tweets.full_text: @lumpenspace Most alignment researchers don’t focus on the paper clipping threat model, they focus on disempowerment threat models (in a way which is fairly agnostic about what AIs will do with the world after gaining control of it).

user.description: studying AI and trust. ex @openai/@googledeepmind, now thinking in public.
user.name: Richard Ngo

tweets.full_text:
In other words: just as we’ll try to align AIs much smarter than us, so too will they try to align AIs much smarter than them.

The weak version of this claim is just that they’ll put effort into it, and they’ll likely do a better job than us. That by itself seems sufficient to make paperclip maximizers implausible.

But there’s also a strong version of the claim: if this is a recurring problem across generations, then sufficiently intelligent agents will identify protocols for cooperation which help solve it.

It’s inefficient for each generation to distrust its descendants. A universe in which all intelligences behave cooperatively towards the (much stupider and less coherent) agents which gave rise to them is a universe which reaps huge gains from trade across time.

I don’t think this makes such cooperation inevitable, no more than the idea of war being irrational reliably prevents war. But it does suggest that we should be on the look out for protocols that apply even across big intelligence gaps, and try to instill them into our AIs.

I recently gave a talk inspired by this idea, on the analogy between how humans should treat animals, how parents should treat children, and how AIs should treat us. Will upload in a few days. I also think that updateless decision theory is relevant here, as one of the few formal treatments of interactions between smart and dumb agents. Will say more about this in some forthcoming blog posts.

user.description: studying AI and trust. ex @openai/@googledeepmind, now thinking in public.
user.name: Richard Ngo

tweets.full_text:
It seems unrealistic to me that a superintelligence will tile the universe with small-scale patterns (like paperclips).

Not because it’s an alien goal from a human perspective.

But because it’s an alien goal from the perspective of its not-yet-superintelligent predecessor AIs.
